text.p: Suppose the linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^5\rightarrow \mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline] has a standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] which row reduces to have 3 pivots. What can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

Suppose the linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^5\rightarrow \mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline] has a standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] which row reduces to have 2 pivots. What can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

Suppose the linear transformation [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^3\rightarrow \mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline] has a standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] which row reduces to have 3 pivots. What can we conclude about [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?

font.p: We know that [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into if and only if its standard matrix row-reduces to have a pivot in every column, and [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is onto if and only if its standard matrix row-reduces to have a pivot in every row.

In the first example, we have a [mathjaxinline]3\times 5[/mathjaxinline] matrix with a pivot in every row but not every column, so [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is onto but not into. (In fact, a linear transformation from [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline] to [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline] can never be into.)

In the second example, we have a [mathjaxinline]3\times 5[/mathjaxinline] matrix with only two pivots, therefore it does not have one in every row nor in every column. Thus [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is neither into nor onto.

Finally, we have a [mathjaxinline]5\times 3[/mathjaxinline] matrix with a pivot in every column, but not every row. Thus [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into but not onto. (In fact, a linear transformation from [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline] to [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^5[/mathjaxinline] can never be onto.)
